Others will not be so kind, but thank you for not pointing out that I placed Oliver North in the wrong branch. Anyway, my question to you was not facetious; something in the back of my brain was bugging me. I've finally remembered what.

Many years ago, I had occasion to ask an employee in a New York State Court what rank would be next above the Major (uniformed Court Officer) I had just been speaking to. Her answer was "Chief"; but it's conceivable that she meant the (non-uniformed) Chief -- who worked in her building -- was next in line above that particular major. That is, maybe other uniformed ranks exist but no one in that building had achieved that rank. The rank directly superior to a Major in the New York State Police is an Inspector of some type ("Staff Inspector"?).

This came back to me after taking random looks at other nations' military ranks. The clue specifies nothing about the uniform worn by the Maj., but I didn't find any situation in which a uniformed Maj. is ranked directly (serially) below COL. (The clue for COL can't use "Lt. Col." or any form thereof, by custom.)

Now, if a COL is the highest rank of "senior officer" (as I read), what is the lowest rank of senior officer (in our Army)?

In 1977 my high school was getting ready to remodel over the summer. I answered a job opening in the daily bulletin. Only 3 of us showed to see about the jobs, so we all got one. It turned out to be jobs for unskilled construction laborers which had to pay, I assume union negotiated, rate for construction laborers.

It paid $20 an hour in 1977 dollars (about $80 today)! In a given week I might spend $25.

I got a BA in Econ Geography & Management Info Sys in 1982 from a Pac-10 univ during the Reagan recession (worst since the 1930s). It took me 3 years to escape the gig economy. I finally got a job paying about $17k working for EDS at a GM plant. I ended up a consultant specializing in the design of materials management systems for manufacturers, with cutting edge knowledge on lean manufacturing, systems design, database design, process modeling, etc... I redesign the material management systems for a major midwest manufacturer. By then my pay had crept up to about $34k. A relative that graduated 3 years before me never made under that & lifetime earnings is 10x mine. Reagan gave me & those after me a shrunken social contract.

I was laid off in 1991-2, I got advanced degrees from tier 1 univ in 2001-3 so I could do a higher order of consulting but was unable to find work after 2005?

In 2012 I got a 4 month gig paying $22/hr designing a database. All that education, experience & I made more in high school as a laborer.

W/out a doubt the U.S. econ system is messed up.

To solve the snake problem, we can imagine starting with the head and forming a chain by adding on open ends one at a time. We form a valid snake body if and only if the tail segment is added on last. So the chance of forming a snake is 12/13 x 10/11 x 8/9 x 6/7 x 4/5 x 2/3 = 0.34099234099... as calculated by Mike O'Connor below.

If we let N be the number of segments excluding the head and tail, the chance of forming a snake computes to the product of (2i)/(2i+1) over all integral values from 1 to N. This expression converges to zero as N approaches infinity.

My father worked for a large brewery as a maintenance supervisor, a similar job to Michelle Obama's father, with almost exact same pay, $55k in 1977 which is almost $250k in today's $.

The brewery could pay him that kind of money because they had high tech, high automation, high speed canning equipment. Not only did he get high pay but everyone that worked there, thousands of people, made a high wage. In turn they spent it on housing, feeding, clothing, educating and raising their families, which pushed the money out into services in the surrounding area.

The issue is not technology and never was, it is the distribution of bargaining power & the associated distribution of wages that go with it.

America is more productive than it has ever been: more than double 1977. The problem is all those gains are going to the top 1% and they can only buy so many goods & services for themselves so the wealth is concentrated up at the top.

This is the classic problem going all the way back to the Roman empire & Ancient Egypt's New Kingdom.

Bargaining power has at least two levels: macro and micro. Micro is the bargaining power distribution between you and your employer, macro is the power your class of cohorts manifests in the making of laws in congress. The two combined determine the distribution of wealth: thru wages, thru taxation, thru monetary policy (inflation forces investors to not sit on their money but invest it in order to get a return & demand allows them to get a return.

I'm a vet.  I went to the VA.  Quite a few times.  When I was passing a kidney stone, they told me to wait in a room along, for 4 hours and told me that they were not giving me anything for the pain because that was what I wanted (I sure did, it HURT, but I wasn't a pain med user, don't even use alcohol or tobacco at all).  When a fell and broke my lower leg and hobbled into the VA ER the MD told me it couldn't be broken or I wouldn't be able to walk on it so sent me away without even an xray.  When I had it treated at a local hospital the VA refused to pay the bill because I should have gone to the local VA center.  When I ran a limbing saw over my left index finger, cutting it down to the bone, the VA center gave me a bandaid and a tetanus shot.  When I went to a local medical clinic and they closed the would with 9 stitches the VA refused to pay the bill because I was supposed to go to my local VA clinic for treatment.  And when I fell and tore the lateral and medial meniscus in my right knee that told me to go away, that they didn't find any value in treating that injury in fat men over 40.  I paid thousands for the surgery from a real medical services provider.  And on and on.  If you need an annual physical, pharmacy meds mailed or an annual flu shot, the VA is fine.  If you need real medical care, the VA Medical Malpractice Center is not the right place to be.

Before I was encouraged to apply for VA medical coverage by a friend, I had no idea that it would be as good as it is. My private insurance (Group Health of Puget Sound) does not give me the individual attention the VA does. By that I mean the VA requires that I come in once a year for a physical. They send the two medications that I take directly to my house at much less cost than Group Health. The VA screened me upon registration for agent orange exposure (I served two tours in places where agent orange was prevalent.). This "debat did three e" is politically motivated. The debate is being engaged in primarily by people who have never seen the inside of a military uniform. Ask my son who did three tours of duty in Iraq and in other areas of the world we find ourselves in. Ask me and my fellow Vietnam vets. My guess is that they will go with the VA as is.

Wherever there is a pool of taxpayer dollars, circling above are vultures looking to fatten up at public expense. Look at our public schools, prisons, space program, etc. What we get is always less than what we wanted and what we had. And there is no accountability for error.

It looks to me like Congress wants to make things so bad -- by sacrificing veterans -- that the public clamors for a fix, one that comports with campaign donations.

as with nearly every other issue, the problem is money in politics. Fix that and government will once again work for the people -- we who ordained and established the constitution.

I am a USNR retiree and I use VA and private care. VA care is great but facility farther away and old (new VA facility under construction). But, private care is no magic bullet. Try to get a dermatologist, cardio or any other specialty as a new patient, e.g. derm was 3 mo. wait at last contact.

The internships most people describe are just entry level jobs. What's wrong with working your way up as opposed to slaving your way up.

In addition they get access to world class facilities, and athletic coaching. It isn't insubstantial compensation. It's an amount from the high teens to 80 thousand annually depending on the school. And ... all of their sports leagues, equipment uniforms are paid for.

By all means add up the cost of your rent, your gym, 5 days per week of personal training then add 18,000 for books and tuition ... plus sports equipment, masseuses, sports nutrition an personal tutors

The comparison is ridiculous.

Poor people have the same need for the basic infrastructure of civilization as anyone else. Indian business and government must band together and make the money and the laws and processes occur that absolutely mandate water, electricity, sewage, roadways, and infrastructure a reality fir all of India's Poor. Corruption and any and all processes that bleed off the money and resources for these efforts must be severely dealt with. Standardize if need be... power plants, sewage plants, and infrastructure elements - then spread them out across the country.

Any country that can create and foster the wealth and industry India now has, including a national space program, can do this. It's a matter of Will and Priorities. The masses deserve better. It's long overdue.
